title: Finding the Vertex Using the Formula

content.explanation:
For a quadratic function in standard form f(x) = ax² + bx + c, the x-coordinate of the vertex can be found using the formula:

x = -b/(2a)

Once we know the x-coordinate, we can find the y-coordinate by substituting this x-value back into the original function:

y = f(-b/(2a))
content.example:
For f(x) = 2x² - 8x + 7:
a = 2, b = -8, c = 7

x-coordinate: x = -(-8)/(2(2)) = 8/4 = 2
y-coordinate: f(2) = 2(2)² - 8(2) + 7 = 8 - 16 + 7 = -1

So the vertex is (2, -1)
content.key_point: The formula x = -b/(2a) comes from calculus by finding where the derivative of the quadratic function equals zero (where the slope is zero), which occurs at the vertex.
